In Dec 2015, 196 countries agreed to the landmark # ParisAgreement on # ClimateChange, pledging to fight the climate crisis. Its goal is to keep this century’s temperature increase well below 2°C, & further, to limit the increase to 1.5°C.

And the response to this tweet by some is testimony to the way that well-meaning folks have been duped and weaponized into a culture war over language, distracting from the task at hand--communicating the distinct threat posed by fossil fuel burning and climate change.

Scientists won’t— and shouldn’t - alter the SCIENTIFIC lexicon for political purposes. People are welcome to characterize climate change as a crisis. It doesn’t mean SCIENTISTS should alter their descriptions of physical processes. I’m disheartened that I even have to say this.

The *physical phenomenon* we are talking about is human-caused *climate change*. That's the term scientists use and *should* use in describing it. The impacts & implications arguably constitute a *crisis*. What terminology is most appropriate depends entirely on the context.

Global warming/climate change are complimentary terms used by scientists depending on context. Climate change refers to changes in the stats — averages AND extremes. We can see the impact in recent unprecedented weather extremes. See my op-Ed: https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/its-not-rocket-science-climate-change-was-behind-this-summers-extreme-weather/2018/11/02/b8852584-dea9-11e8-b3f0-62607289efee_story.html?utm_term=.c7e25a23ab1d …
